content:
Let T\mathcal{T}T be a Lawvere theory with with generating object xxx. This induces an adjunction F:Set⇄T-Alg:UF:\text{Set}\rightleftarrows\mathcal{T}\text{-Alg}:UF:Set⇄T-Alg:U defined by U(A)≔AxU(A)\coloneqq AxU(A):=Ax and F(S)≔T-Alg(xS,−)F(S)\coloneqq \mathcal{T}\text{-Alg}(x^S,-)F(S):=T-Alg(xS,−).

This in turn induces a monad M≔UF:Set→SetM\coloneqq UF : \text{Set}\to\text{Set}M:=UF:Set→Set, sending SSS to T-Alg(xS,x)\mathcal{T}\text{-Alg}(x^S,x)T-Alg(xS,x). Lots of familiar monads come about this way: the list monad, the free group monad, the Maybe monad, etc.

But when we construct a monad this way, we get an additional structure: For any operation o:xn→xo:x^n \to xo:xn→x of T\mathcal{T}T, we get a morphism o‾:M×n→M\overline{o}:M^{\times n} \to Mo:M×n→M defined by (T-Alg(xS,x))n≅T-Alg(xS,xn)→o∗T-Alg(xS,x)(\mathcal{T}\text{-Alg}(x^S,x))^n \cong \mathcal{T}\text{-Alg}(x^S,x^n) \xrightarrow{o_*} \mathcal{T}\text{-Alg}(x^S, x)(T-Alg(xS,x))n≅T-Alg(xS,xn)o∗​​T-Alg(xS,x). Moreover, these morphisms define a product-preserving functor T→End(Set)\mathcal{T}\to \text{End}(\text{Set})T→End(Set) sending x↦Mx\mapsto Mx↦M and o↦o‾o\mapsto \overline{o}o↦o

For example, in the case where T\mathcal{T}T is the theory for a monoid, we find that MMM (the list monad) is a monoid in the category of endofunctors in two different ways: (1) in the monoidal category (End(Set),∘,idSet)(\text{End}(\text{Set}), \circ, \text{id}_{\text{Set}})(End(Set),∘,idSet​), and (2) in the monoidal category (End(Set),×,c1)(\text{End}(\text{Set}), \times, c_1)(End(Set),×,c1​).

Does anyone talk about this sort of monad with extra structure? What can be said about it?

It seems to me that all monads MMM (let's say on Set\mathrm{Set}Set) bear this type of structure, insofar as all monads on Set\mathrm{Set}Set can be construed as infinitary Lawvere theories.

M(j)M(j)M(j) can be thought of as codifying the set of jjj-ary operations of the monad qua theory, in the sense that if XXX is an MMM-algebra, then the algebra structure on XXX induces (via what the nLab calls the "coYoneda lemma") a map

∫jM(j)⋅Xj≅M(X)→X\int^j M(j) \cdot X^j \cong M(X) \to X∫jM(j)⋅Xj≅M(X)→X

hence a map M(j)⋅Xj→XM(j) \cdot X^j \to XM(j)⋅Xj→X dinatural in jjj, hence a map M(j)→Set(Xj,X)M(j) \to \mathrm{Set}(X^j, X)M(j)→Set(Xj,X) natural in jjj which interprets elements in M(j)M(j)M(j) as operations on XXX. And so it would go when we correspondingly think of MMM itself as an MMM-module via the monad multiplication:

∫jM(j)⋅M(−)j≅M∘M→M\int^j M(j) \cdot M(-)^j \cong M \circ M \to M∫jM(j)⋅M(−)j≅M∘M→M

which is what you're describing.

Thanks! This is helpful. The context I'm thinking about is the language NRA in Limsoon Wong's thesis (see https://www.comp.nus.edu.sg/~wongls/psZ/wls-thesis.pdf on page 38). Here I guess we could get the operations M(−)j→MM(-)^j\to MM(−)j→M by the procedure you are describing but you would need the ambient category to be Set\text{Set}Set for sure, and Wong assumes much less in this case --- it is a cartesian category (not even closed!) with a strong monad MMM and then you have operations 1→M1\to M1→M and M×M→MM\times M \to MM×M→M forming a monoid.
(Ugh, finally. I thought I had sent this 6 hours ago, but then noticed it in my drafts folder, and have been struggling to send this again for the past 10 minutes.)
I still only see your message about it
The system seems to be malfunctioning for me.

(Original message)

At this point I'm confused as to what you're asking. It's not true that for any strong monad on a cartesian category, you get a (cartesian) monoid structure on MMM for free: just consider the identity monad.

Something we can say: suppose MMM is a strong monad on a cartesian category C\mathcal{C}C, and (X,α:M(X)→X)(X, \alpha: M(X) \to X)(X,α:M(X)→X) is an MMM-algebra. Then, if JJJ is an object such that XJX^JXJ exists (i.e., if there exists a representing object for the functor C(J×−,X)\mathcal{C}(J \times -, X)C(J×−,X)), then for each morphism t:1→M(J)t: 1 \to M(J)t:1→M(J), we have an accompanying operation XJ→XX^J \to XXJ→X formed as the composite

XJ≅1×XJ→t×idM(J)×XJ→M(J×XJ)→M(X)→αX.X^J \cong 1 \times X^J \overset{t \times \mathrm{id}}{\to} M(J) \times X^J \to M(J \times X^J) \to M(X) \overset{\alpha}{\to} X.XJ≅1×XJ→t×idM(J)×XJ→M(J×XJ)→M(X)→αX.

where the first unlabeled non-isomorphism comes from the strength, and the second is MMM applied to the universal arrow J×XJ→XJ \times X^J \to XJ×XJ→X.

For example, suppose C\mathcal{C}C has finite coproducts and cartesian product distributes over these coproducts. By abuse of notation, let jjj denote the jjj-fold coproduct of copies of the terminal object 111. Then the ordinary cartesian power XjX^jXj gives the above representing object, and for every formal "operation" t:1→M(j)t: 1 \to M(j)t:1→M(j) we can form an actual operation Xj→XX^j \to XXj→X as above, for every MMM-algebra XXX. This applies in particular to algebras of the form M(c)M(c)M(c), and we get operations M(c)j→M(c)M(c)^j \to M(c)M(c)j→M(c) that are natural in ccc, hence a natural operation Mj→MM^j \to MMj→M.
I don't immediately see a way of getting rid of the distributivity requirement. But you see that we can make do with far less than C=Set\mathcal{C} = \mathrm{Set}C=Set.

Todd Trimble said:

The system seems to be malfunctioning for me.

I was having problems with Zulip yesterday, for me sending much smaller messages worked.
Thanks, Patrick. That's what I wound up doing.
